intro: Triodanis biflora, commonly known as the two-flowered triodanis, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes caraway and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as woodlands and wet meadows. Its leaves are pinnately divided, and it produces two small flowers per umbel, giving it its common name. Triodanis biflora is often found in association with other wetland plants and plays a role in supporting local pollinator populations.
